qas.question: In what year was the point-contact transistor invented?
Where were Matare and Welker working when inventing the point-contact transistor?
What was the name of Matare and Welker's transistor?
What was the transistron used for?

answers.text: amplified use in France's telephone network

qas.question: What were Matare and Welker's transistors made of?
When did Heinrich Welker start researching electronics?
When did Matare and Welker realize that Bell Labs had invented a transistor?
Who was in charge of France's telephone network?

context: In <a0_0>1948<a0_0/>, the point-contact transistor was independently invented by German physicists <a1_0>Herbert Mataré and Heinrich Welker<a1_0/> while working at the <a2_0>Compagnie des Freins et Signaux<a2_0/>, a <b9_0>Westinghouse<b9_0/> subsidiary located in <b8_0>Paris<b8_0/>. Mataré had previous experience in developing crystal rectifiers from <b5_0>silicon and germanium<b5_0/> in the German radar effort <b6_0>during World War II<b6_0/>. Using this knowledge, he began researching the phenomenon of "interference" in 1947. By June <b7_0>1948<b7_0/>, witnessing currents flowing through point-contacts, Mataré produced consistent results using samples of germanium produced by Welker, similar to what Bardeen and Brattain had accomplished earlier in December 1947. Realizing that Bell Labs' scientists had already invented the transistor before them, the company rushed to get its "<a3_0>transistron<a3_0/>" into production for <a4_0>amplified use in France's telephone network<a4_0/>.
